awd_abstract_narration:
The Tennessee State University Project Tiger Teach (PTT) project is supporting STEM students who will earn a degree in biology, chemistry or mathematics with teacher certification.  PTT is a collaborative partnership between Tennessee State University and the Metropolitan Nashville Public Schools (MNPS) System, a typical urban system serving 81,003 students, 75% of whom are economically disadvantaged. PTT is targeting four cohorts of 10 undergraduate students each (3 biology, 2 chemistry, and 5 mathematics), over a period of 5 years.  The goals of PTT are to 1) increase the number of highly-qualified certified high school STEM teachers in high-need schools in Nashville, TN; 2) increase teacher diversity with emphasis on recruiting African-American male STEM teachers and 3) provide four years of mentoring and professional development opportunities to graduates.

Recruitment efforts include introduction of PTT to 1) science, mathematics, and undecided majors' orientation classes; 2) area high school career counselors; 3) students in HBCU-UP, Regents Math Academy, and TLSAMP; 4) student organizations and student athletes, and 5) the general public via creation of a web page. Participants are involved in summer institutes that include tutoring high school students in the Math Academy and Tennessee State University's Math and Science Center. By the end of their sophomore year, Noyce Scholars are admitted to the teacher certification program in biology, chemistry or mathematics.

Prior to their senior year, students complete four educational courses and all required content courses in preparation for the MNPS high school-based Residency I and Residency II.  The year-long residency produces highly-qualified teachers who have mastered content knowledge and who understand the learning process and application of assessment results to improve instruction. 

Noyce graduates receive four years of support including mentoring and opportunities for professional development.  Among the professional development topics are strategic planning period, from class to the classroom, improving working conditions, effective communication with administration, current research and trends in education, professional rights and responsibilities, and opportunities for professional growth/training.  The mentoring component consists of professional and social support networking including Facebook and Skype.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The aim of Project Tiger Teach (PTT) was to address critical needs in STEM education by achieving three major goals: increasing the number of highly-qualified certified high school STEM teachers in high-need schools in Nashville, TN; enhancing teacher diversity with emphasis on recruiting African American male STEM teachers; and providing two years of mentoring and professional development opportunities to project graduates.

Recruitment efforts targeted biology, chemistry, and mathematics undergraduates. Project information was disseminated to various communities of interest through a range of targeted strategies. Brochures and flyers were distributed and strategically posted across Tennessee State University (TSU) campus, particularly in locations frequented by STEM students, and with incoming first-year students expressing interest in STEM majors.  Information was shared through emails and in-person advisement sessions, during recruitment trips to area community colleges, and at events such as TSU Day at the Capitol. 

Mentorship was central to the project, with two highly successful mentor teachers (1 science and 1 math) working with participants during summer institutes. The focus of these sessions were to prepare participants for the CORE and Praxis II tests required for teacher licensure, provide mentorship, and skill development to reinforce their confidence as future educators. Additionally, scholars received individualized advisement each semester. These meetings provided an opportunity for students to share their experiences (or express their concerns), which allowed program administrators to assess the participants progress and adjust the curriculum and mentoring strategies as needed.  Tutoring in the Science and Math Lab by participants provided practical experience which reinforced their subject mastery and teaching skills.

Over the course of the program, seventeen students received Noyce Scholarships (17.6% African American (AA) males, 58.8% AA females, 5.9% Caucasian males, 11.8% Caucasian females, 5.9% Other) in the content areas of biology (35.3%), chemistry (5.9%) and math (58.8%).  The funding provided a significant financial resource that allowed participants to pursue their certification and teaching careers. 

Professional development opportunities were provided through workshops, and participation in conferences.  Noyce Scholars, currently enrolled as well as graduates, attended regional and national conferences, including the Southeast Regional Noyce Conference and Noyce Summit. Attending conferences allowed scholars to network with other aspiring STEM teachers, learn from experts in the field, and gain valuable insights into the teaching profession. Classroom teachers were informed of opportunities to submit Classroom Research Grants.  Partnerships with local schools and mentorship arrangements created opportunities for participants to engage in classroom observations. The Biology Mentor Teacher was selected from a group of Tennessee educators to participate in a multistate standard-setting study for the ETS Praxis Biology Test. The project PI served as a member of the Advisory Board for the Southeast Regional Noyce Conference. 

Collaboration has been a hallmark of the project, bridging departments within TSU. Efforts include grant submissions for interdisciplinary research, professional development for educators, and career intervention studies to enhance STEM retention. These initiatives foster innovation and strengthen ties between STEM disciplines and education faculties.

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Elaine D Martin
